sp.ab: If he come not, then the play is marred: it goes not
forward, doth it?

sp.speaker: Quince
sp.ab: It is not possible: you have not a man in all Athens
able to discharge Pyramus but he.

sp.speaker: Flute
sp.ab: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man
in Athens.

sp.speaker: Quince
sp.ab: Yea, and the best person too; and he is a very
paramour for a sweet voice.

sp.speaker: Flute
sp.ab: You must say âparagon:â a paramour is, God bless us, a
thing of naught.

sp.speaker: Snug
sp.ab: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and
there is two or three lords and ladies more
married: if our sport had gone forward, we had all
been made men.

sp.speaker: Flute
sp.ab: O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence
a day during his life; he could not have scaped
sixpence a day: an the duke had not given him
sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll be
hanged; he would have deserved it: sixpence a day in
Pyramus, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bottom
sp.ab: Where are these lads? where are these hearts?

sp.speaker: Quince
sp.ab: Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!

sp.speaker: Bottom
sp.ab: Masters, I am to discourse wonders: but ask me
not what; for if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I
will tell you every thing, right as it fell out.

sp.speaker: Quince
sp.l: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.

sp.speaker: Bottom
sp.ab: Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is,
that the duke hath dined. Get your apparel
together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons
to your pumps; meet presently at the palace;
every man look o'er his part; for the short and
the long is, our play is preferred. In any case,
let Thisby have clean linen; and let not him that
plays the lion pare his nails, for they shall
hang out for the lion's claws. And, most dear
actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to
utter sweet breath; and I do not doubt but to
hear them say, it is a sweet comedy. No more words:
away! go, away!

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.l: 'Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: More strange than true: I never may believe
These antique fables, nor these fairy toys.
Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,
Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend
More than cool reason ever comprehends.
The lunatic, the lover and the poet
Are of imagination all compact:
One sees more devils than vast hell can hold,
That is, the madman: the lover, all as frantic,
Sees Helen's beauty in a brow of Egypt:
The poet's eye, in a fine frenzy rolling,
Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven;
And as imagination bodies forth
The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen
Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing
A local habitation and a name.
Such tricks hath strong imagination,
That, if it would but apprehend some joy,
It comprehends some bringer of that joy:
Or in the night, imagining some fear,
How easy is a bush supposed a bear!

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.l: But all the story of the night told over,
And all their minds transfigured so together,
More witnesseth than fancy's images
And grows to something of great constancy;
But, howsoever, strange and admirable.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth. Enter LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HERMIA, and HELENA.
Joy, gentle friends! joy and fresh days of love
Accompany your hearts!

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.l: More than to us
Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Come now; what masques, what dances shall we have,
To wear away this long age of three hours
Between our after-supper and bed-time?
Where is our usual manager of mirth?
What revels are in hand? Is there no play,
To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?
Call Philostrate.

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: Here, mighty Theseus.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Say, what abridgement have you for this evening?
What masque? what music? How shall we beguile
The lazy time, if not with some delight?

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: There is a brief how many sports are ripe:
Make choice of which your highness will see first. Giving a paper.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: âThe battle with the Centaurs, to be sung
By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.â
We'll none of that: that have I told my love,
In glory of my kinsman Hercules. Reads âThe riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,
Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.â
That is an old device; and it was played
When I from Thebes came last a conqueror. Reads âThe thrice three Muses mourning for the death
Of Learning, late deceased in beggary.â
That is some satire, keen and critical,
Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony. Reads âA tedious brief scene of young Pyramus
And his love Thisbe; very tragical mirth.â
Merry and tragical! tedious and brief!
That is, hot ice and wondrous strange snow.
How shall we find the concord of this discord?

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long,
Which is as brief as I have known a play;
But by ten words, my lord, it is too long,
Which makes it tedious; for in all the play
There is not one word apt, one player fitted:
And tragical, my noble lord, it is;
For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess,
Made mine eyes water; but more merry tears
The passion of loud laughter never shed.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: What are they that do play it?

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,
Which never laboured in their minds till now,
And now have toiled their unbreathed memories
With this same play, against your nuptial.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: And we will hear it.

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: No, my noble lord;
It is not for you: I have heard it over,
And it is nothing, nothing in the world;
Unless you can find sport in their intents,
Extremely stretched and conned with cruel pain,
To do you service.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: I will hear that play;
For never any thing can be amiss,
When simpleness and duty tender it.
Go, bring them in: and take your places, ladies. Exit Philostrate.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.l: I love not to see wretchedness o'ercharged
And duty in his service perishing.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.l: He says they can do nothing in this kind.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing.
Our sport shall be to take what they mistake:
And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect
Takes it in might, not merit.
Where I have come, great clerks have purposed
To greet me with premeditated welcomes;
Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,
Make periods in the midst of sentences,
Throttle their practised accent in their fears
And in conclusion dumbly have broke off,
Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, sweet,
Out of this silence yet I picked a welcome;
And in the modesty of fearful duty
I read as much as from the rattling tongue
Of saucy and audacious eloquence.
Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity
In least speak most, to my capacity. Re-enter PHILOSTRATE.

sp.speaker: Philostrate
sp.l: So please your grace, the Prologue is addressed.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Let him approach. Flourish of trumpets. Enter QUINCE for the Prologue.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: If we offend, it is with our good will,
That you should think, we come not to offend,
But with good will. To show our simple skill,
That is the true beginning of our end.
Consider then we come but in despite.
We do not come as minding to content you,
Our true intent is. All for your delight
We are not here. That you should here repent you,
The actors are at hand and by their show
You shall know all that you are like to know.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: This fellow doth not stand upon points.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he
knows not the stop. A good moral, my lord: it is not
enough to speak, but to speak true.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: Indeed he hath played on this prologue like a
child on a recorder; a sound, but not in government.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: His speech was like a tangled chain; nothing impaired,
but all disordered. Who is next?
sp.stage: Enter PYRAMUS and THISBE, WALL,MOONSHINE, and LION.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show;
But wonder on, till truth make all things plain.
This man is Pyramus, if you would know;
This beauteous lady Thisby is certain.
This man, with lime and rough-cast, doth present
Wall, that vile Wall which did these lovers sunder;
And through Wall's chink, poor souls, they are content
To whisper. At the which let no man wonder.
This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn,
Presenteth Moonshine; for, if you will know,
By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn
To meet at Ninus' tomb, there, there to woo.
This grisly beast, which Lion hight by name,
The trusty Thisby, coming first by night,
Did scare away, or rather did affright;
And, as she fled, her mantle she did fall,
Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain.
Anon comes Pyramus, sweet youth and tall,
And finds his trusty Thisby's mantle slain;
Whereat, with blade, with bloody blameful blade,
He bravely broached his boiling bloody breast;
And Thisby, tarrying in mulberry shade,
His dagger drew, and died. For all the rest,
Let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and lovers twain
At large discourse, while here they do remain, Exeunt Prologue, Pyramus, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: I wonder if the lion be to speak.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: No wonder, my lord; one lion may, when many asses do.

sp.speaker: Wall
sp.l: In this same interlude it doth befall
That I, one Snout by name, present a wall:
And such a wall, as I would have you think,
That had in it a crannied hole or chink,
Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisby,
Did whisper often very secretly.
This loam, this rough-cast and this stone doth show
That I am that same wall; the truth is so:
And this the cranny is, right and sinister,
Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard
discourse, my lord.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: Pyramus draws near the wall: silence!

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: O grim-looked night! O night with hue so black!
O night, which ever art when day is not!
O night, O night! alack, alack, alack,
I fear my Thisby's promise is forgot!
And thou, O wall, O sweet, O lovely wall,
That stand'st between her father's ground and mine!
Thou wall, O wall, O sweet and lovely wall,
Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne! Wall holds up his fingers.
Thanks, courteous wall: Jove shield thee well for this!
But what see I? No Thisby do I see.
O wicked wall, through whom I see no bliss!
Curst be thy stones for thus deceiving me!

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse
again.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.ab: No. in truth, sir, he should not. âDeceiving meâ
is Thisby's cue: she is to enter now, and I am
to spy her through the wall. You shall see, it will
fall pat as I told you. Yonder she comes.

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: O wall, full often hast thou heard my moans,
For parting my fair Pyramus and me!
My cherry lips have often kissed thy stones,
Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in thee.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: I see a voice: now will I to the chink,
To spy an I can hear my Thisby's face.
Thisby!

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: My love thou art, my love I think.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover's grace;
And, like Limander, am I trusty still.

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: And I like Helen, till the Fates me kill.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true.

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: O, kiss me through the hole of this vile wall!

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: I kiss the wall's hole, not your lips at all.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: Wilt thou at Ninny's tomb meet me straightway?

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: 'Tide life, 'tide death, I come without delay. Exeunt Pyramus and Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Wall
sp.l: Thus have I, Wall, my part discharged so;
And, being done, thus Wall away doth go. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: Now is the moon used between the two neighbours.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: No remedy, my lord, when walls are so wilful to hear
without warning.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst
are no worse, if imagination amend them.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: If we imagine no worse of them than they of
themselves, they may pass for excellent men. Here come
two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.

sp.speaker: Lion
sp.l: You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts do fear
The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor,
May now perchance both quake and tremble here,
When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar.
Then know that I, as Snug the joiner, am
A lion fell, nor else no lion's dam;
For, if I should as lion come in strife
Into this place, 'twere pity on my life.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: A very gentle beast, and of a good conscience.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: The very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: This lion is a very fox for his valour.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: True; and a goose for his discretion.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: Not so, my lord; for his valour cannot carry his
discretion; and the fox carries the goose.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his
valour; for the goose carries not the fox. It is
well: leave it to his discretion, and let us listen to
the moon.

sp.speaker: Moon
sp.l: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present; â

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: He should have worn the horns on his head.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: He is no crescent, and his horns are invisible within
the circumference.

sp.speaker: Moon
sp.l: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;
Myself the man i' the moon do seem to be.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: This is the greatest error of all the rest: the
man should be put into the lanthorn. How is it else
the man i' the moon?

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: He dares not come there for the candle; for, you see,
it is already in snuff.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: I am aweary of this moon: would he would change!

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: It appears, by his small light of discretion that
he is in the wane; but yet, in courtesy, in all
reason, we must stay the time.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: Proceed, Moon.

sp.speaker: Moon
sp.ab: All that I have to say, is, to tell you that the
lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon;
this thorn-bush, my thorn-bush; and this dog, my dog.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn; for
all these are in the moon. But, silence! here comes
Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: This is old Ninny's tomb. Where is my love?

sp.speaker: Lion
sp.ab: O â

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: Well roared, Lion.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: Well run, Thisbe.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: Well shone, Moon. Truly, the moon shines with a good
grace.
sp.stage: The Lion shakes Thisbe's mantle, and exit.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.l: Well moused, Lion.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: And then came Pyramus.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: And so the lion vanished.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams;
I thank thee, Moon, for shining now so bright;
For, by thy gracious, golden, glittering gleams,
I trust to take of true Thisby sight.
But stay, O spite!
But mark, poor knight,
What dreadful dole is here!
Eyes, do you see?
How can it be?
O dainty duck! O dear!
Thy mantle good,
What, stained with blood!
Approach, ye Furies fell!
O Fates, come, come,
Cut thread and thrum;
Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: This passion, and the death of a dear friend, would go
near to make a man look sad.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.

sp.speaker: Pyramus
sp.l: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?
Since lion vile hath here deflowered my dear:
Which is â no, no â which was the fairest dame
That lived, that loved, that liked, that looked with cheer.
Come, tears, confound;
Out, sword, and wound
The pap of Pyramus;
Ay, that left pap,
Where heart doth hop: Stabs himself.
Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.
Now am I dead,
Now am I fled;
My soul is in the sky:
Tongue, lose thy light;
Moon, take thy flight: Exit Moonshine.
Now die, die, die, die, die. Dies.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: No die, but an ace, for him; for he is but one.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: Less than an ace, man; for he is dead; he is nothing.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover, and
yet prove an ass.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: How chance Moonshine is gone before Thisbe comes back
and finds her lover?

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: She will find him by starlight. Here she comes; and
her passion ends the play.

sp.speaker: Hippolyta
sp.ab: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a
Pyramus: I hope she will be brief.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: A mote will turn the balance, which Pyramus,
which Thisbe, is the better; he for a man, God warrant
us; she for a woman, God bless us.

sp.speaker: Lysander
sp.ab: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: And thus she means, videlicet: â

sp.speaker: Thisbe
sp.l: Asleep, my love?
What, dead, my dove?
O Pyramus, arise!
Speak, speak. Quite dumb?
Dead, dead? A tomb
Must cover thy sweet eyes.
These lily lips,
This cherry nose,
These yellow cowslip cheeks,
Are gone, are gone:
Lovers, make moan:
His eyes were green as leeks.
O Sisters Three,
Come, come to me,
With hands as pale as milk;
Lay them in gore,
Since you have shore
With shears his thread of silk.
Tongue, not a word:
Come, trusty sword;
Come, blade, my breast imbrue: Stabs herself.
And, farewell, friends;
Thus Thisby ends:
Adieu, adieu, adieu. Dies.

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

sp.speaker: Demetrius
sp.ab: Ay, and Wall too.

sp.speaker: Bottom
sp.ab: No, I assure you; the wall is down that parted
their fathers. Will it please you to see the
epilogue, or to hear a Bergomask dance between two of
our company?

sp.speaker: Theseus
sp.ab: No epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs no
excuse. Never excuse; for when the players are
all dead, there need none to be blamed. Marry,
if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged
himself in Thisbe's garter, it would have been
a fine tragedy: and so it is, truly; and very
notably discharged. But, come, your Bergomask: let
your epilogue alone.
sp.l: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve:
Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time.
I fear we shall outsleep the coming morn
As much as we this night have overwatched.
This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled
The heavy gait of night. Sweet friends, to bed.
A fortnight hold we this solemnity,
In nightly revels and new jollity. Exeunt, Enter PUCK.

sp.speaker: Puck
sp.l: Now the hungry lion roars
And the wolf behowls the moon;
Whilst the heavy ploughman snores,
All with weary task fordone.
Now the wasted brands do glow,
Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud,
Puts the wretch that lies in woe
In remembrance of a shroud.
Now it is the time of night
That the graves all gaping wide,
Every one lets forth his sprite,
In the church-way paths to glide:
And we fairies, that do run
By the triple Hecate's team,
From the presence of the sun,
Following darkness like a dream,
Now are frolic: not a mouse
Shall disturb this hallowed house:
I am sent with broom before,
To sweep the dust behind the door. Enter OBERON and TITANIA wlith their train.

sp.speaker: Oberon
sp.l: Through the house give glimmering light,
By the dead and drowsy fire:
Every elf and fairy sprite
Hop as light as bird from brier;
And this ditty, after me,
Sing, and dance it trippingly.

sp.speaker: Titania
sp.l: First, rehearse your song by rote,
To each word a warbling note:
Hand in hand, with fairy grace,
Will we sing, and bless this place. Song and dance.

sp.speaker: Oberon
sp.l: Now, until the break of day,
Through this house each fairy stray.
To the best bride-bed will we,
Which by us shall blessed be;
And the issue there create
Ever shall be fortunate.
So shall all the couples three
Ever true in loving be;
And the blots of Nature's hand
Shall not in their issue stand;
Never mole, hare-lip, nor scar,
Nor mark prodigious, such as are
Despised in nativity,
Shall upon their children be.
With this field-dew consecrate,
Every fairy take his gait;
And each several chamber bless,
Through this palace, with sweet peace;
And the owner of it blest
Ever shall in safety rest.
Trip away; make no stay;
Meet me all by break of day. Exeunt Oberon, Titania, and train.

sp.speaker: Puck
sp.l: If we shadows have offended,
Think but this, and all is mended,
That you have but slumbered here
While these visions did appear.
And this weak and idle theme,
No more yielding but a dream,
Gentles, do not reprehend:
If you pardon, we will mend:
And, as I am an honest Puck,
If we have unearned luck
Now to scape the serpent's tongue,
We will make amends ere long;
Else the Puck a liar call;
So, good night unto you all.
Give me your hands, if we be friends,
And Robin shall restore amends. Exit,
